title-group.article-title: SOME LESSONS FROM INFORMAL FINANCIAL PRACTICES IN RURAL TANZANIA

abstract.p: Efforts to develop rural financial markets in low income countries by using formal banks have experienced many difficulties and failures. Development economists are increasingly recognising the importance of learning from the operations of informal financial markets. This paper explores informal financial practices that take place in the Kilimanjaro region of Tanzania. The aim is to identify operational features of informal financial practices that have implications for the development of formal institutions. Survey data from Kilimanjaro show that rural dwellers successfully resolve financial problems through informal means. Farmers save informally by hoarding crop harvests and by keeping livestock that are low yielding but resistant to diseases and resilient to harsh climatic conditions, eg the short horn-zebu cattle. Informal borrowing, both in cash and kind takes place between friends, relatives and neighbours. A traditional agistment agreement is widely practised and helps farmes to acquire livestock - a lucrative diversification from the low paying major cash crop - coffee. Stereotype money-lenders do not exist in the study area. However, private commercial lenders who also manage other forms of trade or business provide rural dwellers with credit for a wide range of purposes. Most important ones include food for families facing deficits, finances and equipment needed to send children to boarding schools and material for house construction. Advise, counselling and support are important components of such credit. Lessons for formal financial institutions centre on the observed ability and willingness to save, the close relationship between borrowers and lenders, fiduciary elements and trust in credit transactions, the role that traditional leaders play in enforcing financial agreements, strong measures taken on defaulters, the focus on the needs as expressed by the rural dwellers and the apparent importance of consumption credit.
